section.title: Audience
section.para: This document is intended for software developers and system administrators. It assumes basic experience with software packaging and package repositories, as well as with system installation, system and application configuration, and software updating. Background knowledge in XML file creation and editing, XML Includes (XInclude), the XML Path Language (XPath), system automation using BASH or other scripting languages, and networking and machine virtualization will also assist the reader.

section.title: What's Not Covered
section.para: This manual complements several Deploy documents. The "Installation Instructions" and "Getting Started Guide" provide basic information about obtaining and installing Deploy. The "Deploy Definition File Reference" (DDFR) contains the syntax for definition elements and attributes. Finally, Deploy has a set of man pages explaining the deploy command, its options and the Deploy configuration file, deploy.conf. This manual contains references to all four throughout the text.
These Deploy documents are available at the Deploy website.

section.title: How to Read
section.para: The intent of the manual is to help you use Deploy effectively to deploy and maintain systems and applications using software package repositories. This manual takes a top-down approach, explaining the concepts before giving steps, commands and examples that you can use to create and test your own repositories.

section.title: Conventions Used
section.para: The document conventions are alphabetically listed below.

listitem.para: Command names in Deploy or function names in other programs appear throughout the document.

Elements and attributes in XML are referred to by their XPath equivalents. The active node is always considered to be the root, repo; thus, the first element in the XPath expression is the top-level element, while subsequent elements/attributes are its children. Top-level elements in the DDFR and their child elements use the parent/child/child format, while @attribute-names are preceded by an @ symbol. The assumed parent element is repo. For more details on XPath syntax, see XML Path Language.
Code examples appear in a box, displayed below.

informalexample.programlisting: <!-- This is a comment in an example code section -->

listitem.para: Filenames, folder names, directory trees and file extensions all use a monospace format.
Critical items appear with an "Important" set off tag:

important.para: The main top-level element is required.

listitem.para: Within definition examples, the traditional XML comment tags "<!--" and "-->" contain notes. See Also .
A set-off tag highlights things that a user needs to know.

note.para: The top-level elements can be in any order in the definition.

listitem.para: Computer output to the screen can be inline computer output, usually in Courier monospace font, or included in a box, as in the case below.
Commands entered by the user appear as inline commands or formatted as an . If the latter, then special characters indicate different users, as shown below.

informalexample.programlisting:
# precedes lines entered as a root user
$ precedes lines entered as a normal user

listitem.para: Deploy variables are presented in monospace font, e.g. %{id}.
